Can any of you in other parts of the country start a similar workshop?
IT11 be passing along reports of related ideas, experiments, and
training and hiring efforts by other educational radio and television
stations as they come in. Several stations have reported a sincere desire
to hire blacks but point to a lack of preparedness on the part of job
applicants. The Urban Workshop suggests one possible answer.
Nov; what about you and your station? Silence doesnTt necessarily
indicate inactivity, but if you are involved, then why not take that next
logical step and involve yourself where the good things you are doing can
be shared at the national level? Let me ask you the following:
What programs for, by or about Disadvantaged citizens is your
station working on?
What ideas are on the drawing board?
Can you share funding solutions with other NER stations?
What good program ideas failed in their production and why?
How have you "plugged in" to the inner city on the rural ghetto
in your part of the country?
Where do you find most support for such programming? Municipal
government? School Boards? Church organizations?
Are you training anyone from Disadvantaged groups in communication
skills with a view toward staff employment?
Have you found hiring Negroes on your staff facilitates a more
meaningful station approach to this programming? If so, in what ways?
What is the value of a black production unit?
Do any of your programs get replay on local commercial stations
where such stations have a larger coverage pattern than your own?
These are only a few of the questions. You are raising others every
day as you decide your own stationTs approach to programming for the
Disadvantaged. It is your answers, based on your own first hand experience
that I hope you will share with us.
